abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Research Project for
            Zaire is rated as unsatisfactory and sustainability of even
            the modest institutional reforms is uncertain. The project
            was approved by the Board on August 20, 1991. Subsequently,
            military-led riots broke out in several parts of Zaire,
            which led to widespread looting and the evacuation of most
            foreigners. As a result, the credit did not become effective
            until December 8, 1992. Following effectiveness, project
            activities moved slowly because of the difficult political
            and economic circumstances. These included non-payment of
            civil servant salaries, lack of counterpart funding,
            liquidity problems in the banks, hyper-inflation, and the
            continuing absence of technical staff. Additional riots in
            1993 further complicated project implementation because of
            looting and deteriorating security. As with other projects
            in Zaire, disbursements were suspended indefinitely on July
            15, 1993. On November 15, 1993, because the Government had
            failed to meet its debt service obligation, Zaire was placed
            in non-accrual status and the Bank decided to close all
            credits to the country. On March 4, 1994, IDA closed the
            credit and canceled the undisbursed balance. Only eight
            percent had been disbursed, of which three-quarters was used
            for project preparation. No audit is planned. Notably, the
            project managed to achieve the close collaboration of all
            donor agencies funding agricultural research, including an
            agreement to merge independent research programs under a
            single national structure. This provides a potential basis
            for future coordination.
